question.name: 18.3.2.3 Location of stationary points
question.questiontext:
Example

Find a second stationary point of \(f(x,y)=8x^2+6y^2-2y^3+5\).

Solution

\(f_x=16x\) and \(f_y\equiv 6y(2-y)\).

From this we note that \(f_x=0\) when \(x=0\), and \(f_y=0\) when \(y=0\).

So \(x=0,\ y=0\)

i.e. \((0,0)\) is a second stationary point of the function.

It is important when solving the simultaneous equations \(f_x=0\) and \(f_y=0\) to find stationary points not to miss any solutions. A useful tip is to factorise the left-hand sides and consider systematically all the possibilities.

Example

Locate the stationary points of \(f(x,y)=x^4+y^4-36xy\)

Solution

First we write down the partial derivatives of \(f(x,y)\)

\(\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}=4x^3-36y=4(x^3-9y)\)

\(\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}=4y^3-36x=4(y^3-9x)\)

Now we solve the equations \(\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}=0\) and \(\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}=0\):

\(x^3-9y = 0 \\ \) (i)

\(y^3-9x = 0 \\ \) (ii)

From (ii) we obtain

\(x = \dfrac{y^3}{9}\) (iii)

Now substitute from (iii) into (i)

\(\dfrac{y^9}{9^3}-9y = 0\\ \) \(\Rightarrow y^9-9^4y = 0\\ \)

\(\Rightarrow y(y^8-3^8) = 0 \) (removing the common factor) \( \\ \)

\(\Rightarrow y(y^4-3^4)(y^4+3^4) = 0 \) (using the difference of two squares)\( \\ \)

We therefore obtain as the only solutions:

\(y=0\) or \(y^4-3^4 = 0\) (since \(y^4+3^4\) is never zero) \( \\ \)

The last equation implies:

\((y^2-9)(y^2+9) = 0\) (using the difference of two squares) \( \\ \)

therefore \(y^2=9\) and \(y =\pm\ 3\).

Now, using (iii): when \(y=0,\ x=0\), when \(y=3,\ x=3\), and when \(y=-3,\ x=-3\).

The stationary points are \((0,0), (-3,-3)\) and \((3,3)\).

Example

Locate the stationary points of \(f(x,y)=x^4+y^4-36xy\)

Solution

\(\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}=3x^2-3,\\ \dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}=2y-6\)

Now solve simultaneously the equations \(\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}=0\) and \(\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial y}=0\):

\(3x^2-3=0\) and \(2y-6=0\).

Hence \(x^2=1\) and \(y=3\), giving stationary points at \((1,3)\) and \((-1,3)\).

Key Point

The Partial Derivative of \(\pmb f\) with respect to \(\pmb x\)

For a function of two variables \(z=f(x,y)\) the partial derivative of \(f\) with respect to \(x\) is denoted by \(\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}\) and is obtained by differentiating \(f(x,y)\) with respect to \(x\) in the usual way but treating the \(y\)-variable as if it were a constant.

Alternative notations for \(\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}\) are \(f_x(x,y)\) or \(f_x\) or \(\dfrac{\partial z}{\partial x}\)

Example

    Find \(\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}\) for

  1. \(f(x,y)=x^3+x+y^2+y\),
  2. \(f(x,y)=x^2y+xy^3\).

Solution

  1. \(\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}=3x^2+1+0+0=3x^2+1\)
  2. \(\dfrac{\partial f}{\partial x}=2x\times y+1\times y^3=2xy+y^3\)
